The Navy Yard has more than 2,000 permanent jobs on site, and provides an estimated 3,000 temporary jobs to crews of film and television shoots at Steiner Studios. Introduction.description: As the threats of climate change increase, destructive storms like Superstorm Sandy, Hurricane Katrina, and Hurricane Harvey will expose the vulnerabilities of costal communities overburdened by industrial and chemical facilities. Of interest are NYC’s Significant Maritime and Industrial Areas (SMIAs), clusters of industry and polluting infrastructure along the waterfront. SMIAs are located in classic environmental justice communities- predominantly low-income communities of color - in the south Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, which are also hurricane storm surge zones. The WJP is a research and advocacy campaign focusing on community resiliency that seeks to reduce potential toxic exposures and public health risks associated with climate change and storm surge in the City’s industrial waterfront.

Kill Van Kull.description: The Kill Van Kull SMIA stretches from Howland Hook to Snug Harbor. It contains a concentration of maritime uses including a marine terminal and dry docks for ship repair. The SMIA is approximately 665 acres and zoned to permit a broad range of commercial and industrial uses. In 2008, there were more than 70 firms employing more than 3,300 people in the SMIA. The overwhelming number of jobs - more than 70 percent - were in transportation and warehousing. (Text taken from NYC VISION 2020)

Newtown Creek.description: Newtown Creek, at over 780 acres the city’s largest SMIA, is adjacent portions of the Greenpoint, Williamsburg, Long Island City, and Maspeth industrial areas. The waterfront area is characterized by heavy industry and municipal facilities, many of which are water-dependent. (Text taken from NYC VISION 2020)

Red Hook.description: The Red Hook SMIA is approximately 120 acres and is more than 90 percent publicly owned. The SMIA is home to the Red Hook Container Terminal and Brooklyn Piers Port Authority Marine Terminal. (Text taken from NYC VISION 2020)

South Bronx.description: The South Bronx SMIA is more than 850 acres in size, stretching from Port Morris on the Harlem River to Hunts Point on the East River. Wholesale trade is the dominant industry. The SMIA is home to the city's produce distribution center at Hunts Point, the Fulton Fish market, and other food distributors. (Text taken from NYC VISION 2020)

Staten Island West Shore.description: Staten Island West Shore is a new SMIA designated after the original six. This is an area under development and as the population and maritime industry in the area increase, more will be known about how the SMIA designation of this area relates to the local industry and demographics. (See: NYS EDC Working Westshore 2030)

Sunset Park.description: Nearly 600 acres, the Sunset Park SMIA extends from Erie Basin to Owl's Head, an area characterized by water-dependent facilities, concentrations of industrial activity, well-buffered manufacturing districts, and vacant sites and brownfields of significant size. A small portion of the SMIA abuts the Gowanus Canal, a waterway that was designated a Superfund Site in 2010. (Text taken from NYC VISION 2020)

data.pageText: As the threats of climate change increase, destructive storms like Superstorm Sandy, Hurricane Katrina, and Hurricane Harvey will expose the vulnerabilities of costal communities overburdened by industrial and chemical facilities. Of interest are NYC’s Significant Maritime and Industrial Areas (SMIAs), clusters of industry and polluting infrastructure along the waterfront. SMIAs are located in classic environmental justice communities- predominantly low-income communities of color - in the south Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, which are also hurricane storm surge zones. The WJP is a research and advocacy campaign focusing on community resiliency that seeks to reduce potential toxic exposures and public health risks associated with climate change and storm surge in the City’s industrial waterfront.

Significant Maritime and Industrial Areas (SMIAs) are zones designated under the Waterfront Revitalization Project in order to encourage the protection and siting of industrial and maritime uses alon gthe waterfront. There are only seven SMIAs in the city, all located in predominatly low-income, communities of color. NYC-EJA's research has shown that the SMIAs are all in storm surge zones, and that the City of New York had not analyzed the cumulative contamination exposure risks associated with clusters of heavy industrial use.

This map shows the seven SMIAs (outlined in solid black) as well as a half mile buffer to SMIAs (outlined in a dashed line) to determine communities located in close proximity. Half a mile is the distance often used to study environmental impact under NY's environmental regulatory framework.

This map shows the percentage of population of people of color by census tract. Census tracts in dark purple denote areas where more than 66% of the community are people of color. As you can see, the majority of areas around SMIAs represent populations of color. In fact, of the total 5.5 million people of color in NYC, 2.8 million in census tracts that are vulnerable to storm surge and approximately 430,000 live in census tracts that are both vulnerable to storm surage and fall with a half-mile of SMIAs.

This land use map shows that industrial and manufacturing uses are concentrated in the SMIAs. The SMIAs are purple accounting for "industrial and manufacturing" uses, but these areas are surrounded by shares of yellow, denoting the presence of residential uses. Note that this map does not take into account non-conforming uses where former manufacturing buildings are being used for residential use, as is the case in Greenpoint or Williamsburg.

data.pageLayer: Percent of Families Below Poverty Line
data.pageText: This map shows the percentage of families below poverty level population by census tract. Census tracts with dark red denote areas where more than 66% of the community is below poverty level. In fact of the total X million low-income population in NYC. 1.6 million live in census tracts that are vulnerable to hurricane storm surge, and 283,000 live in census tracts that are both vulnerable to storm surge and fall within a half-mile of SMIAs.

Similarly, this map shows the median household income of families by census tract. Census tracts which are dark green indicate lower income households. Many low income households live in or in half-mile proximity to SMIAs.

Furthermore, using data from the NYC department of Health and Mental Hygiene we can see that SMIAs and the adjacent areas include some of the highest levels of the uninsured people by community district (dark blue), which denotes limited access to health insurance in the event of a toxic exposure. Note that that in hatched community districts, estimates of percent uninsured should be interepreted with caution.
Hurricane evacuation zones, provided by NYC  emergency management, show that SMIAs are highly vulnerable to hurricane damage. This presents a threat to communities who live in such areas.

This map shows facilies handling hazardous substances or toxic chemicals in these areas that could represent a threat in the event of hurricane storm sturge. Among these are NY State DEC regulated class 2 Superfund sites - sites determined to pose significant threat to pulic health or the environment and requiring immediate action. We also show NYS DEC regulated active bulk chemical and major oil storage facilities, which store hazardous substances or have the capacity to store 400,000 gallons of oil. Finally we show the location of facilities reporting chemicals in the Toxics Release Inventory under the US EPA Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know act.

The SMIAs and their surroundings are highly vulnerable to hurricane storm surge. This map shows that the SMIA boundaries and storm surge zones (as defined by the NYS Emergency Management Office). Facilities handling hazardous substances or toxic chemicals in these areas could represent a threat in the event of a hurricane storm storm surge.

As we have shown, SMIAs and their surroundings have many industrial and toxic industries, as well as being vulnerable to storms and being home to more people of color, people below poverty line, and people without insurance. The combination of these factors creates a situation where the communities near SMIAs are vulnerable to possible toxic waste spillage in the event of storms.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard is a 227-acre publicly owned industrial park characterized by a diversity of small businesses. The Navy Yard has more than 2,000 permanent jobs on site, and provides an estimated 3,000 temporary jobs to crews of film and television shoots at Steiner Studios. The robust increase in business activity between 200 and 2008 is attributed to a dramatic redevelopment effort, harnessing more than $500 million in public and private investment. (Source: VISION 2020)

Newtown Creek, at over 780 acres the city’s largest SMIA, abuts portions of the Greenpoint, Williamsburg, Long Island City, and Maspeth industrial areas. The waterfront area is characterized by heavy industry and municipal facilities, many of which are water-dependent. (Source: VISION 2020)

Moreover, in the Newtown Creek SMIA, there are potentially vulnerable bulk storage sites. Shown is the location of NY State DEC regulated Class 2 Superfund Sites -- sites determined to pose significant threat to public health or the environment & requiring immediate action. Of the total 43 sites in NYC, 8 of them (or 19%) are both vulnerable to storm surge and located within half a mile of the Newtown Creek SMIA.

This is an area under development and as the population and maritime industry in the area increase, more will be known about how the SMIA designation of this area relates to the local industry and demographics. (See: NYS EDC Working Westshore 2030)

The Red Hook SMIA is approximately 120 acres and is more than 90 percent publicly owned. The SMIA is home to the Red Hook Container Terminal and Brooklyn Piers Port Authority Marine Terminal. (Source: VISION 2020)

The South Bronx SMIA is more than 850 acres in size, stretching from Port Morris on the Harlem River to Hunts Point on the East River. Wholesale trade is the dominant industry. The SMIA is home to the city\'s produce distribution center at Hunts Point, the Fulton Fish market, and other food distributors. (Source: VISION 2020)

In the South Bronx SMIA, of particular note are the locations of NY State DEC regulated active chemical bulk and major oil storage facilities. These facilities store hazardous substances or have the capacity to store 400,000 gallons of oil. Of the 171 facilities in NYC, 18 of them or 11% are both vulnerable to storm surge and located within half a mile of the South Bronx SMIA. Currently the NYC Industrial Waterfront Project is working to help implement polution prevention, toxics reduction and climate adaption strategies with the goal of making the South Bronx industrial waterfront sustainable and climate resilient.

Nearly 600 acres, the Sunset Park SMIA extends from Erie Basin to Owl\'s Head, an area characterized by water-dependent facilities, concentrations of industrial activity, well-buffered manufacturing districts, and vacant sites and brownfields of significant size. A small portion of the SMIA abuts the Gowanus Canal, a waterway that was designated a Superfund Site in 2010. (Source: VISION 2020)

Furthermore, the Sunset park SMIA contains potentially vulnerable facilites containg toxic chemicals. Shown is the location of facilities reporting chemicals in the Toxics Release Inventory under the US EPA Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act. Of the 234 TRI Reporters in NYC, 17 of them or 7% are both vulnerable to storm surge and located within half a mile of the Sunset Park SMIA. Currently RAND and NYC-EJA is taking a grassroots research-to-action approach to improve community resiliency in Sunset Park.

The Kill Van Kull SMIA stretches from Howland Hook to Snug Harbor. It contains a concentration of maritime uses including a marine terminal and dry docks for ship repair. The SMIA is approximately 665 acres and zoned to permit a broad range of commercial and industrial uses. In 2008, there were more than 70 firms employing more than 3,300 people in the SMIA. The overwhelming number of jobs - more than 70 percent - were in transportation and warehousing. (Source: VISION 2020)

As shown in these maps, the presence of vulnerable communities, manufacturing, and toxic waste in areas susceptible to storm damage could create a threat to communities in these areas. More work is needed to understand how these communities are threatened and what can be done to alleviate the threat.
